A hulking being with a dragon's head and a patchwork of black, blue, green, red, and white scales for skin lurches forward on two legs, raising clawed fists into the air. Dragonflesh golems are rare constructs created from the remains of dead chromatic dragons.

entries.name: Built from Dragon Corpses
entries: Dragonflesh golems are powerful, but building such a creature requires great expense beyond the normal costs to create most other golems. The crafter must use the remains of five dragons, one of each color, of adult age or older. Mages looking to construct dragonflesh golems often hire adventurers to acquire the bodies they need.

entries.name: Powered by Dragon Blood
entries: Dragonflesh golems require frequent infusions of dragon blood to remain operational. This blood does not need to come from a true dragon; any creature with draconic blood will suffice.

entries.name: Construct Nature
entries: The dragonflesh golem doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

monster.name: Vine Golem

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with adamantine weapons

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Bound
entries: The vine golem is psychically bound to its creator and can communicate telepathically with its creator as long as neither is {@condition incapacitated}. In addition, each knows the distance to and direction of the other. The golem and its creator don't have to be on the same plane of existence to communicate telepathically, but they do have to be on the same plane to know each other's distance and direction.

trait.name: Creator's Eyes and Ears
entries: As a bonus action, the creator can see through the vine golem's eyes and hear what it hears until the start of the creator's next turn, gaining the benefits of the vine golem's {@sense darkvision}. During this time, the creator is {@condition deafened|phb|deaf} and {@condition blinded|phb|blind} with regard to its own senses. While using the construct's senses, the creator can cast a spell through the vine golem, using those senses to target the spell. The range, area, and effect of the spell are calculated as if the spell originated from the vine golem, not the master, though the master must still cast the spell on the master's turn. Spells that require concentration must be maintained by the master.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The vine golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The vine golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Plant Camouflage
entries: The vine golem has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks it makes in any terrain that contains ample obscuring plant life.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vine golem makes two thorned vine attacks.

action.name: Thorned Vine
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be pulled up to 10 feet toward the vine golem.

action.name: Thorned Embrace
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one Medium or smaller creature. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 11}). Until the grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the vine golem can't embrace another target.
A humanoid-shaped tangle of green vines shambles through a portal and gives a friendly wave.

entries.name: Druid Servants
entries: Vine golems are constructs created by druids for use as scouts and guardians. These plant-like constructs maintain a psychic connection with their creators, who can see through their eyes and cast spells through them. The golem-creator connection is maintained across the planes of the multiverse and is severed only if the construct or the druid dies. The vine golem is made from a variety of rare plants and flowers found only in the depths of old-growth forests. The process of creating a vine golem is closely guarded by cabals of druids, who will sometimes gift worthy druids with the knowledge in the form of a {@item manual of golems|dmg|manual of vine golems}.

entries.name: Golems without Creators
entries: When a vine golem's creator dies, the construct carries out the druid's final orders and then retreats to the nearest wilderness. Driven by a psyche fractured from the loss of its creator, the vine golem guards the animals and plants of its chosen home with extreme prejudice, attacking all intruders, regardless of any previous affiliation they might have had with its creator.

entries.name: Construct Nature
entries: A vine golem doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The graknork has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The graknork makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws. Alternatively, it can use its Eye Ray twice. If both claw attacks hit a Large or smaller creature, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or take an additional 9 ({@damage 2d8}) slashing damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +12} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 3d10 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Eye Ray
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +9} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 5d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Freezing Eye {@recharge 5}
entries: The graknork's blue eye flares open and releases a beam of icy energy in a line that is 120-feet long and 10 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) cold damage and is {@condition restrained} for 1 minute as its limbs freeze. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition restrained}. A {@condition restrained} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. Alternatively, the {@condition restrained} creature can be freed if it takes at least 10 fire damage.

Towering over the frozen landscape, this immense saurian monstrosity possesses a terrifying shark-like head with a multitude of serrated teeth. The monster has three eyes: two soulless black pits and a third larger eye that glows with a freezing blue light.

entries.name: Terror of the North
entries: The legendary graknork is one of the most powerful monsters to roam the endless tundra and taiga of the north and is feared by all who live in the rugged and frozen expanses of the world. Only the largest white dragons surpass the graknork in size and strength, and lesser creatures give the monster a wide berth. Graknorks are mostly found on land but are reasonable swimmers. They have no problem taking to the water to pursue escaping prey or to hunt fishermen and even whales. Graknorks are solitary creatures and cannot stand the presence of their own kind, attacking and eating juvenile graknorks that cross their path. When they do mate, it is a destructive affair with the female uprooting dozens of trees to build her nest. A typical graknork is more than forty feet long, though even larger specimens have been sighted in the coldest regions of the world.

entries.name: Great Blue Eye
entries: While the graknork's raw physical prowess is justifiably feared, the aspect of its appearance that causes the greatest consternation is its great, freezing blue eye. Its eye is said to possess terrible and wondrous powers, including seeing through illusions, freezing souls outright, and causing everlasting blizzards. Most of these tales are mere fancy and hearsay spun by northern tribesmen, yet there is no denying that the graknork's central eye is a fearsome weapon.

trait.name: Elemental Aura
entries: At the start of each of the graveyard dragon's turns, each creature within 5 feet of it takes 4 ({@damage 1d8}) damage of the type dealt by the dragon's breath weapon.

trait.name: Elemental Resistance
entries: The graveyard dragon has resistance to the type of damage dealt by its breath weapon.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the graveyard dragon remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a pile of dragon bones.

trait.name: Reassemble Bones
entries: As a bonus action, the graveyard dragon can rearrange its bone structure to fit into a space as narrow as 1 foot wide without squeezing. It can use a bonus action to reassemble itself into its normal form. While in this compressed form, it can't make melee weapon attacks.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The graveyard dragon makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d10 + 3}) piercing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) acid/lightning/poison/fire/cold damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} bis zum Treffer, Reichweite 5 ft., ein Ziel. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) Hiebschaden.

action.name: Breath Weapon {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragon releases a breath weapon that corresponds to the type of dragon it was in life. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 40 ({@damage 9d8}) damage of the corresponding type on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

items.name: Black.
items.entry: Acid damage in a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide.

items.name: Blue.
items.entry: Lightning damage in a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide.

items.name: Green.
items.entry: Poison damage in a 30-foot cone.

items.name: Red.
items.entry: Fire damage in a 30-foot cone.

items.name: White.
items.entry: Cold damage in a 30-foot cone.

entries: This draconic skeleton is surround by a nimbus of light, colored in such a way as to betray the undead creature's living origins.

Graveyard dragons form out of the remains of evil dragons killed as part of a cataclysm that claimed the lives of several dragons at the same time, or when their remains are exposed to heavy concentrations of necrotic energy. One of the most prominent homes of such dragons is the Dragon Graveyard on the edge of the Ghoul Imperium.

entries.name: Vindictive Undead
entries: Graveyard dragons are vengeful, like many other intelligent undead, but they focus their retribution on the ones responsible for their deaths rather than on their own kind. In fact, these undead dragons have a strange sense of protectiveness of other dragons, particularly for the type of dragons they were when they were alive. This sometimes extends to non-evil dragons, but most good-aligned dragons view the existence of graveyard dragons with distaste.

entries.name: Intimidating Appearance
entries: Graveyard dragons are particularly appealing to powerful undead as guardians for their lairs. A graveyard dragon's skeletal appearance is often enough to scare away most adventurers and tomb robbers. Unlike a more traditional animated skeleton, however, the graveyard dragon is capable of handling the few tomb robbers foolhardy enough to face it.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: The graveyard dragon doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Antimagic Susceptibility
entries: The swarm is {@condition incapacitated} while in the area of an {@spell antimagic field}. If targeted by {@spell dispel magic}, the swarm must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against the caster's spell save DC or fall {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute.

trait.name: Deafening Clatter
entries: A creature in the swarm's space is {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the greed swarm remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal pile of coins and valuables.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny object. Except for Gather, the swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

action.name: Coin Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the greed swarm's space. {@h}10 ({@damage 4d4}) bludgeoning damage, or 5 ({@damage 2d4}) bludgeoning damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

action.name: Coin Barrage
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +5} to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) bludgeoning damage, 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

action.name: Gather (1/Day)
entries: The swarm magically gathers up to 100 gp worth of coins, gems, and other small, valuable objects within 60 feet of it, adding them to its mass. It regains 7 ({@damage 2d6}) hit points and has advantage on its next attack roll. A creature wearing or carrying such valuables must succeed on a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw or its valuables fly toward the swarm, joining the mass.
The sound of metal clinking against metal becomes a deafening cacophony as a swirling cloud of coins mindlessly hunts for more valuables to absorb into its everexpanding mass.

Located in densely-populated areas, the greed swarm is solely focused on increasing the size of its hovering collection of valuables. Able to differentiate between objects of value and worthless junk, the swarm stalks streets and sewers alike. Its movements are erratic; the cloud swells and contracts in quick succession, repositioning itself in jerky, stilted bursts of motion.

entries.name: Bad Penny
entries: The swarm consists of normal, mundane valuables animated by a magical master coin. Often mistaken as a standard regional coin, this master coin is created in a dark ritual to serve as a vessel for pure, ceaseless avarice. If the master coin is destroyed or separated from the swarm, the remaining coins return to their normal inert state and fall to the ground.

entries.name: All that Glitters
entries: The master coin cannot exert its power without a large enough supply of valuables to control in close proximity. Bank and vault owners who fail to screen incoming coinage for latent magical properties may find themselves in need of adventurers to discreetly quell a storm of their accumulated wealth. Wishing wells and public fountains are also common homes for greed swarms.

entries.name: Construct Nature
entries: The greed swarm doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: The Three Swarms of Mammon
entries: In Midgard, clerics of the arch-devil {@creature mammon, archduke of greed|ToB|Mammon} ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}) recall the sacred tale of the three greed swarms which appeared when Mammon's avatar arrived atop Demon Mountain by way of an infernally-corrupted shadow road. The swarms descended upon Tintager in the West, Stannasgard in the North, and Runkelstad in the East. After achieving gargantuan sizes, the swarms departed for the Hells, taking with them a vast hoard that resides in Mammon's vaults to this day.

trait.name: Aura of Drunkenness
entries: The rum lord radiates an aura of drunkenness to a radius of 20 feet. Each creature that starts its turn in the aura must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. A creature that has consumed alcohol within the past hour has disadvantage on the saving throw. While {@condition poisoned}, a creature falls {@condition prone} if it tries to move more than half its speed during a turn. A creature that succeeds on the saving throw is immune to the rum gremlin lord's Aura of Drunkenness for 24 hours.

trait.name: Hearty
entries: The rum lord adds its Constitution modifier to its AC (included in the Armor Class).

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The rum lord has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: One for the Road
entries: When the rum lord hits a {@condition poisoned} enemy with any weapon, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d6} poison damage.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The rum lord's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 13}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The rum lord makes two attacks: one with its ale tap scepter and one with its broken bottle shiv.

action.name: Ale Tap Scepter
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Broken Bottle Shiv
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} bis zum Treffer, Reichweite 5 ft., ein Ziel. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) Stich-Schaden.

action.name: Rotgut Belch {@recharge 6}
entries: The rum lord vomits green bile in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a target takes 18 ({@damage 4d8}) poison damage and is covered in green bile for 1 minute. On a success, a target takes half the damage and isn't covered in bile. A creature, including the target, can take an action to wipe off the bile. {@creature rum gremlin|ToB|Rum gremlins} have advantage on attack rolls against creatures covered in a rum lord's green bile.

action.name: Bring Me Another Round! (1/Day)
entries: The rum lord lets out a thunderous belch, calling {@dice 1d4} {@creature rum gremlin|ToB|rum gremlins} ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}). The called {@creature rum gremlin|ToB|rum gremlins} arrive in {@dice 1d4} rounds, acting as allies of the lord and obeying its spoken commands. The {@creature rum gremlin|ToB|rum gremlins} remain for 1 hour, until the lord dies, or until the lord dismisses them as a bonus action.
A large gremlin rises from a hollowed-out barrel throne and belches loudly, wielding a wood spigot tap as a scepter in one hand and a broken bottle in the other.

entries.name: Drunken Kings
entries: Rum lords attract other {@creature rum gremlin|ToB|rum gremlins} ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}) into a court of drunken debauchery. Rum lords are known for entertaining guests of some notoriety within the darker circles of society, especially {@creature wererat|mm|wererats} and {@creature ratfolk|ToB} ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}). Like all rum gremlins, the rum lord loves alcohol, and wise petitioners bring rare and exotic alcohol to the lord before asking for aid.

entries.name: Rival Drinkers
entries: Rum lords have a special hatred for creatures that take up residence in taverns and alehouses in their territory, especially {@creature clurichaun|ToB|clurichauns} ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}), {@creature alehouse drake|ToB|alehouse drakes} ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}), and other rum lords.

entries.name: Tougher Than the Rest
entries: Stronger than their kin in body and mind, rum lords aren't bothered by bells like rum gremlins. In spite of this, rum lords aren't overly cruel to their minions and often go out of their way to remove bells from their territory. This kindness doesn't extend to disobedient rum gremlins, and a rum lord always keeps one bell tucked away, just in case.

monster.name: Grimmlet
languages: understands Void Speech but can't speak

trait.name: Reproduce
entries: When a grimmlet takes damage from a spell and isn't reduced to 0 hp, a number of new grimmlets equal to the spell's level appear in unoccupied spaces within 10 feet of the grimmlet. If the spell is a cantrip, only one grimmlet is created. Sixteen or more grimmlets within 30 feet of each other can use their reactions to come together and form a {@creature grimmlet swarm|ToB2} in a space within 5 feet of one grimmlet.

trait.name: Self-destruct
entries: When the grimmlet dies, it explodes in a spray of Void-infused crystal shards. Each creature within 5 feet of the grimmlet must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or take 3 ({@damage 1d6}) slashing damage and 3 ({@damage 1d6}) psychic damage. Grimmlets damaged by this trait don't Reproduce.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The grimmlet's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12}, {@hit 4} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:
footerEntries: {@color *if using {@i Deep Magic for 5th Edition}, replace the indicated spells with {@i crushing curse} and {@i maddening whispers}, respectively|777}

action.name: Crystal Edge
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) slashing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) psychic damage.
A jagged shard of smoky translucent crystal, approximately the size and mass of a housecat, hovers silently across the field.

entries.name: Strange Families
entries: Grimmlets reproduce by creating near clones of themselves when injured by arcane energy, leading them to quickly gather in large familial {@creature grimmlet swarm|ToB2|swarms}. Strangely, a grimmlet can only swarm with other grimmlets created from the same progenitor grimmlet, which leads the swarm. Not long after the swarm forms, it disperses, each grimmlet moving on to create new swarms through magic injury.

entries.name: Whispering Menace
entries: Grimmlets do not speak. In fact, they never communicate with other creatures via any known form of language or telepathy, though they do seem to understand creatures of the Void. Despite this, the air around a grimmlet mutters and whispers at all times in a foul-sounding invocation. When the creature uses its innate magic, these whispers rise in volume slightly, giving canny listeners a split-second warning that something, likely unpleasant, is about to occur.

entries.name: Grimmlets in Midgard
entries: Grimmlets arrive in the mortal realm from the same portion of the Void that spawned the Waste Walker Kb'r'ck of Crystal. Grimmlets were named in honor of the unfortunate tracker who discovered them, Aleksei Grimmczyk. Aleksei did not survive this initial meeting, but his demise was recounted by his friend, the elfmarked mage Alethrie.

monster.name: Grimmlet Swarm
languages: understands Void Speech but can't speak

trait.name: Enervating Maelstrom
entries: When the grimmlet swarm dies, it explodes in a plume of ennui. Each creature within 20 feet of the grimmlet swarm must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) psychic damage and suffers one level of {@condition exhaustion}. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and doesn't suffer {@condition exhaustion}. {@creature grimmlet|ToB2|Grimmlets} damaged by this trait don't Reproduce.

trait.name: Maze of Edges
entries: A creature that attempts to move out of or through the grimmlet swarm must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take 9 ({@damage 2d8}) slashing damage.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The grimmlet swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny {@creature grimmlet|ToB2}. The swarm can't regain hp or gain temporary hp.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The grimmlet swarm's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:
footerEntries: {@color *if using {@i Deep Magic for 5th Edition}, replace the indicated spells with {@i maddening whispers}, {@i crushing curse}, and {@i void strike}, respectively|777}

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The grimmlet swarm makes two attacks with its crystal edges.

action.name: Crystal Edges
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 0 ft., one creature in the swarm's space. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d8}) slashing damage, or 9 ({@damage 2d8}) damage if the swarm has half of its hp or fewer. The target must make a {@dc 17} Intelligence saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
A jagged shard of smoky translucent crystal, approximately the size and mass of a housecat, hovers silently across the field.

entries.name: Strange Families
entries: Grimmlets reproduce by creating near clones of themselves when injured by arcane energy, leading them to quickly gather in large familial swarms. Strangely, a {@creature grimmlet|ToB2} can only swarm with other grimmlets created from the same progenitor grimmlet, which leads the swarm. Not long after the swarm forms, it disperses, each grimmlet moving on to create new swarms through magic injury.

entries.name: Whispering Menace
entries: Grimmlets do not speak. In fact, they never communicate with other creatures via any known form of language or telepathy, though they do seem to understand creatures of the Void. Despite this, the air around a grimmlet mutters and whispers at all times in a foul-sounding invocation. When the creature uses its innate magic, these whispers rise in volume slightly, giving canny listeners a split-second warning that something, likely unpleasant, is about to occur.

entries.name: Grimmlets in Midgard
entries: Grimmlets arrive in the mortal realm from the same portion of the Void that spawned the Waste Walker Kb'r'ck of Crystal. Grimmlets were named in honor of the unfortunate tracker who discovered them, Aleksei Grimmczyk. Aleksei did not survive this initial meeting, but his demise was recounted by his friend, the elfmarked mage Alethrie.

monster.name: Guiguai
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Ethereal Sight
entries: The guiguai can see 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane when it is on the Material Plane, and vice versa.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The guiguai can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Peachwood Weapons
entries: Guiguai are particularly vulnerable to weapons made from the wood of the peach tree. When the guiguai is hit by a weapon made of peachwood, it takes damage as if the weapon was magical.

trait.name: Sunlight Vulnerability
entries: While in sunlight, the guiguai has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, and it loses its resistance to nonmagical weapons.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The guiguai can make one withering touch attack or two necrotic bolt attacks.

action.name: Withering Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 4d6 + 3}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Necrotic Bolt
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +5} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Etherealness
entries: The guiguai enters the Ethereal Plane from the Material Plane, or vice versa. It is visible on the Material Plane while it is in the Border Ethereal, and vice versa, yet it can't affect or be affected by anything on the other plane, with the exception of peachwood weapons.

In some locations, the walls between the worlds of the living and the dead are thin. For the inhabitants of these areas, it is more important than ever to perform proper burial rites, for the smallest mistake could give rise to a guiguai.

entries.name: Lifelike Appearance
entries: If a guiguai does not look a living creature in the eye, it is indistinguishable from how it appeared in life. Once the ghost's gaze meets a living creature's gaze, its ghostly nature becomes apparent.

entries.name: Sins of Life
entries: While most ghosts result from the improper burial of a body, guiguai arise due to funeral rites that do not properly atone for the dead individual's unique sins in life. Restitution to the gods must be made to negate the weight of a person's sins pulling them back to the world of the living.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: The guiguai doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Manifestation
entries: When creating a {@filter guiguai|bestiary|search=guiguai|source=ToB2}, you must choose how the guiguai manifests. Each guiguai manifests in a way unique to the sinful life it led before it died. A manifestation adds one or more features to the base guiguai or adjusts its current features. Each guiguai must have at least one manifestation, but it can have more. Increase the guiguai's challenge rating by 1 for each manifestation you add to it beyond the first manifestation.

entries.name: Bagui, Drought Ghost
entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids who lived lives filled with greed, lust, and gluttony. In death, they seek to scour that which they once consumed with their scorching wind. A {@creature bagui|ToB2} retains its statistics except as noted below.

entries.name: New Action: Desiccating Wind {@recharge 5}
entries: The bagui exhales a breath of burning wind and choking dust. Nonmagical liquids within 30 feet of the guiguai that aren't being worn or carried immediately turn to dust. Each creature within 30 feet of the bagui that isn't a construct or an undead must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 11 ({@damage 2d10}) necrotic damage and 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Plants, oozes and creatures with the Amphibious, Water Breathing, or Water Form traits have disadvantage on this saving throw.

entries.name: Meigui, Trickster Ghost
entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids who caused great disorder during their lives. In death, they exist to spread chaos. A {@creature meigui|ToB2} retains its statistics except as noted below.

entries.name: New Action: Cause Chaos
entries: The meigui chooses up to three creatures it can see within 30 feet of it. Each target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or behave as if affected by the {@spell confusion} spell for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the meigui's Cause Chaos for the next 24 hours.

entries.name: New Action: Change Shape
entries: The meigui magically polymorphs into a {@filter Tiny or Small beast commonly found on a farm that has a challenge rating no higher than its own|bestiary|size=T;S|challenge rating=[&0;&4]}, or back into its true form. It reverts to its true form if it dies. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying is absorbed or borne by the new form (the meigui's choice).

In the new form, the guiguai loses its Incorporeal Movement and Necrotic Aura traits and its size changes to that of the new form. Its statistics and capabilities are otherwise replaced by those of the new form, except any class features or legendary actions of that form.

entries.name: Gudugui, Venomous Ghost
entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids who were hateful to others during their lives. In death, they are compelled to spread their hate like a poison. A {@creature gudugui|ToB2} retains its statistics except as noted below.

entries.name: New Action: Poisonous Touch
entries: The gudugui replaces its Withering Touch with the following action:

items.name: Poisonous Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) poison damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

entries.name: New Action: Insect Scream {@recharge 5}
entries: The gudugui spews insects out of its mouth in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 9 ({@damage 2d8}) piercing damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Xiqigui, Spelleating Ghost
entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids whose lives were consumed with the search for arcane power. In death, their appetite continues, compelling them to seek out and consume spell energy. A {@creature xiqigui|ToB2} retains its statistics except as noted below.

entries.name: Resistances
entries: The xiqigui no longer has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks. It has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from magical attacks. Magical weapons made of peachwood ignore these resistances.

entries.name: New Trait: Spell Absorption Aura
entries: The xiqigui replaces its Incorporeal Movement trait with the following trait:

items.name: Spell Absorption Aura
entries: When a spellcaster within 20 feet of the xiqigui casts a spell, or when the xiqigui is the target of a spell, the spell fails and has no effect if the spell is 3rd level or lower, and the xiqigui regains hp equal to twice the level of the spell.

entries.name: Laogui, Elder Ghost
entries: If a guiguai has 3 or more manifestations, it becomes an elder ghost. The {@filter laogui|bestiary|source=ToB2|search=guiguai|challenge rating=[&6;&30]} has the following action option in addition to the other statistical changes it earns from its other manifestations:

entries.name: New Action: Call Lesser Guiguai (1/Day)
entries: The laogui magically calls 1 {@creature shadow}. The {@creature shadow} arrives in {@dice 1d4} rounds, acts as an ally of the laogui, and obeys its verbal commands. The {@creature shadow} remains for 1 hour, until the laogui dies, or until the laogui dismisses it as a bonus action.

Plants, oozes and creatures with the Amphibious, Water Breathing, or Water Form traits have disadvantage on this saving throw.

entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids who caused great disorder during their lives. In death, they exist to spread chaos. A {@creature meigui|ToB2} retains its statistics except as noted below.

If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the meigui's Cause Chaos for the next 24 hours.

entries: The meigui magically polymorphs into a {@filter Tiny or Small beast commonly found on a farm that has a challenge rating no higher than its own|bestiary|size=T;S|challenge rating=[&0;&4]}, or back into its true form. action.name: Etherealness
entries: The guiguai enters the Ethereal Plane from the Material Plane, or vice versa. It is visible on the Material Plane while it is in the Border Ethereal, and vice versa, yet it can't affect or be affected by anything on the other plane, with the exception of peachwood weapons.

action.name: Cause Chaos
entries: The meigui chooses up to three creatures it can see within 30 feet of it. Each target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or behave as if affected by the {@spell confusion} spell for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the meigui's Cause Chaos for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Change Shape
entries: The meigui magically polymorphs into a {@filter Tiny or Small beast commonly found on a farm that has a challenge rating no higher than its own|bestiary|size=T;S|challenge rating=[&0;&4]}, or back into its true form. It reverts to its true form if it dies. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying is absorbed or borne by the new form (the meigui's choice).

In the new form, the guiguai loses its Incorporeal Movement and Necrotic Aura traits and its size changes to that of the new form. Its statistics and capabilities are otherwise replaced by those of the new form, except any class features or legendary actions of that form.

In some locations, the walls between the worlds of the living and the dead are thin. For the inhabitants of these areas, it is more important than ever to perform proper burial rites, for the smallest mistake could give rise to a {@creature guiguai|ToB2}.

entries.name: Lifelike Appearance
entries: If a guiguai does not look a living creature in the eye, it is indistinguishable from how it appeared in life. Once the ghost's gaze meets a living creature's gaze, its ghostly nature becomes apparent.

entries.name: Sins of Life
entries: While most ghosts result from the improper burial of a body, guiguai arise due to funeral rites that do not properly atone for the dead individual's unique sins in life. Restitution to the gods must be made to negate the weight of a person's sins pulling them back to the world of the living.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: The guiguai doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Manifestation
entries: Each guiguai manifests in a way unique to the sinful life it led before it died.

entries.name: Meigui, Trickster Ghost
entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids who caused great disorder during their lives. In death, they exist to spread chaos.

monster.name: Gudugui
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Ethereal Sight
entries: The guiguai can see 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane when it is on the Material Plane, and vice versa.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The guiguai can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Peachwood Weapons
entries: Guiguai are particularly vulnerable to weapons made from the wood of the peach tree. When the guiguai is hit by a weapon made of peachwood, it takes damage as if the weapon was magical.

trait.name: Sunlight Vulnerability
entries: While in sunlight, the guiguai has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, and it loses its resistance to nonmagical weapons.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The guiguai can make one poisonous touch attack or two necrotic bolt attacks.

action.name: Poisonous Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) poison damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Necrotic Bolt
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +5} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Etherealness
entries: The guiguai enters the Ethereal Plane from the Material Plane, or vice versa. It is visible on the Material Plane while it is in the Border Ethereal, and vice versa, yet it can't affect or be affected by anything on the other plane, with the exception of peachwood weapons.

action.name: Insect Scream {@recharge 5}
entries: The gudugui spews insects out of its mouth in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 9 ({@damage 2d8}) piercing damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

In some locations, the walls between the worlds of the living and the dead are thin. For the inhabitants of these areas, it is more important than ever to perform proper burial rites, for the smallest mistake could give rise to a {@creature guiguai|ToB2}.

entries.name: Gudugui, Venomous Ghost
entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids who were hateful to others during their lives. In death, they are compelled to spread their hate like a poison.

languages: any languages it knew in life

entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids who caused great disorder during their lives. In death, they exist to spread chaos.

entries.name: Xiqigui, Spelleating Ghost
entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids whose lives were consumed with the search for arcane power. In death, their appetite continues, compelling them to seek out and consume spell energy.

monster.name: Gudu-xiqigui
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Ethereal Sight
entries: The guiguai can see 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane when it is on the Material Plane, and vice versa.

trait.name: Spell Absorption Aura
entries: When a spellcaster within 20 feet of the xiqigui casts a spell, or when the xiqigui is the target of a spell, the spell fails and has no effect if the spell is 3rd level or lower, and the xiqigui regains hp equal to twice the level of the spell.

trait.name: Peachwood Weapons
entries: Guiguai are particularly vulnerable to weapons made from the wood of the peach tree. When the guiguai is hit by a weapon made of peachwood, it takes damage as if the weapon was nonmagical.

trait.name: Sunlight Vulnerability
entries: While in sunlight, the guiguai has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, and it loses its resistance to nonmagical weapons.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The guiguai can make one poisonous touch attack or two necrotic bolt attacks.

action.name: Poisonous Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) poison damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Necrotic Bolt
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +5} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Etherealness
entries: The guiguai enters the Ethereal Plane from the Material Plane, or vice versa. It is visible on the Material Plane while it is in the Border Ethereal, and vice versa, yet it can't affect or be affected by anything on the other plane, with the exception of peachwood weapons.

action.name: Insect Scream {@recharge 5}
entries: The gudugui spews insects out of its mouth in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 9 ({@damage 2d8}) piercing damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

In some locations, the walls between the worlds of the living and the dead are thin. For the inhabitants of these areas, it is more important than ever to perform proper burial rites, for the smallest mistake could give rise to a {@creature guiguai|ToB2}.

entries.name: Lifelike Appearance
entries: If a guiguai does not look a living creature in the eye, it is indistinguishable from how it appeared in life. Once the ghost's gaze meets a living creature's gaze, its ghostly nature becomes apparent.

entries.name: Sins of Life
entries: While most ghosts result from the improper burial of a body, guiguai arise due to funeral rites that do not properly atone for the dead individual's unique sins in life. Restitution to the gods must be made to negate the weight of a person's sins pulling them back to the world of the living.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: The guiguai doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Manifestation
entries: Each guiguai manifests in a way unique to the sinful life it led before it died.

entries.name: Gudugui, Venomous Ghost
entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids who were hateful to others during their lives. In death, they are compelled to spread their hate like a poison.

entries.name: Xiqigui, Spelleating Ghost
entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids whose lives were consumed with the search for arcane power. In death, their appetite continues, compelling them to seek out and consume spell energy.

monster.name: Ba-mei-gudu-laogui
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Ethereal Sight
entries: The guiguai can see 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane when it is on the Material Plane, and vice versa.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The guiguai can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Peachwood Weapons
entries: Guiguai are particularly vulnerable to weapons made from the wood of the peach tree. When the guiguai is hit by a weapon made of peachwood, it takes damage as if the weapon was magical.

trait.name: Sunlight Vulnerability
entries: While in sunlight, the guiguai has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, and it loses its resistance to nonmagical weapons.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The guiguai can make one poisonous touch attack or two necrotic bolt attacks.

action.name: Poisonous Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) poison damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Necrotic Bolt
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +5} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Etherealness
entries: The guiguai enters the Ethereal Plane from the Material Plane, or vice versa. It is visible on the Material Plane while it is in the Border Ethereal, and vice versa, yet it can't affect or be affected by anything on the other plane, with the exception of peachwood weapons.

action.name: Desiccating Wind {@recharge 5}
entries: The bagui exhales a breath of burning wind and choking dust. Nonmagical liquids within 30 feet of the guiguai that aren't being worn or carried immediately turn to dust. Each creature within 30 feet of the bagui that isn't a construct or an undead must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 11 ({@damage 2d10}) necrotic damage and 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Plants, oozes and creatures with the Amphibious, Water Breathing, or Water Form traits have disadvantage on this saving throw.

action.name: Cause Chaos
entries: The meigui chooses up to three creatures it can see within 30 feet of it. Each target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or behave as if affected by the {@spell confusion} spell for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the meigui's Cause Chaos for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Change Shape
entries: The meigui magically polymorphs into a {@filter Tiny or Small beast commonly found on a farm that has a challenge rating no higher than its own|bestiary|size=T;S|challenge rating=[&0;&6]}, or back into its true form. It reverts to its true form if it dies. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying is absorbed or borne by the new form (the meigui's choice).

In the new form, the guiguai loses its Incorporeal Movement and Necrotic Aura traits and its size changes to that of the new form. Its statistics and capabilities are otherwise replaced by those of the new form, except any class features or legendary actions of that form.

action.name: Insect Scream {@recharge 5}
entries: The gudugui spews insects out of its mouth in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 9 ({@damage 2d8}) piercing damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Call Lesser Guiguai (1/Day)
entries: The laogui magically calls 1 {@creature shadow}. The {@creature shadow} arrives in {@dice 1d4} rounds, acts as an ally of the laogui, and obeys its verbal commands. The {@creature shadow} remains for 1 hour, until the laogui dies, or until the laogui dismisses it as a bonus action.

In some locations, the walls between the worlds of the living and the dead are thin. For the inhabitants of these areas, it is more important than ever to perform proper burial rites, for the smallest mistake could give rise to a {@creature guiguai|ToB2}.

entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids who lived lives filled with greed, lust, and gluttony. In death, they seek to scour that which they once consumed with their scorching wind.

entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids who caused great disorder during their lives. In death, they exist to spread chaos.

entries.name: Laogui, Elder Ghost
entries: If a guiguai has 3 or more manifestations, it becomes an elder ghost.

In the new form, the guiguai loses its Incorporeal Movement and Necrotic Aura traits and its size changes to that of the new form. Its statistics and capabilities are otherwise replaced by those of the new form, except any class features or legendary actions of that form.

action.name: Insect Scream {@recharge 5}
entries: The gudugui spews insects out of its mouth in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 9 ({@damage 2d8}) piercing damage and 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Call Lesser Guiguai (1/Day)
entries: The laogui magically calls 1 {@creature shadow}. The {@creature shadow} arrives in {@dice 1d4} rounds, acts as an ally of the laogui, and obeys its verbal commands. The {@creature shadow} remains for 1 hour, until the laogui dies, or until the laogui dismisses it as a bonus action.

In some locations, the walls between the worlds of the living and the dead are thin. For the inhabitants of these areas, it is more important than ever to perform proper burial rites, for the smallest mistake could give rise to a {@creature guiguai|ToB2}.

entries.name: Lifelike Appearance
entries: If a guiguai does not look a living creature in the eye, it is indistinguishable from how it appeared in life. Once the ghost's gaze meets a living creature's gaze, its ghostly nature becomes apparent.

entries.name: Sins of Life
entries: While most ghosts result from the improper burial of a body, guiguai arise due to funeral rites that do not properly atone for the dead individual's unique sins in life. Restitution to the gods must be made to negate the weight of a person's sins pulling them back to the world of the living.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: The guiguai doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Manifestation
entries: Each guiguai manifests in a way unique to the sinful life it led before it died.

entries.name: Bagui, Drought Ghost
entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids who lived lives filled with greed, lust, and gluttony. In death, they seek to scour that which they once consumed with their scorching wind.

entries.name: Meigui, Trickster Ghost
entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids who caused great disorder during their lives. In death, they exist to spread chaos.

entries.name: Gudugui, Venomous Ghost
entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids who were hateful to others during their lives. In death, they are compelled to spread their hate like a poison.

entries.name: Xiqigui, Spelleating Ghost
entries: This manifestation occurs in humanoids whose lives were consumed with the search for arcane power. In death, their appetite continues, compelling them to seek out and consume spell energy.

entries.name: Laogui, Elder Ghost
entries: If a guiguai has 3 or more manifestations, it becomes an elder ghost.

trait.name: Death Burst
entries: The gulper behemoth explodes when it drops to 0 hp. Each creature within 40 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage on a failed save.

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The gulper behemoth can't use its {@sense blindsight} while {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The gulper behemoth has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The gulper behemoth can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}40 ({@damage 6d10 + 7}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the gulper behemoth can't bite another target.

action.name: Swallow
entries: The gulper behemoth makes one bite attack against a Large or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, the creature is also swallowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the behemoth, and it takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the behemoth's turns.

If the gulper behemoth takes 20 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the behemoth must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the behemoth. If the behemoth dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 15 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Sonic Pulse {@recharge 5}
entries: The gulper behemoth expels a sonic pulse in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) thunder damage and is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. On a success, the creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition stunned}.
The titanic eel-like creature has delicately dancing frills and flickers of phosphorescence just under its translucent skin. Its mouth opens impossibly wide as it surges forward.

entries.name: Deep Sea Lure
entries: The gulper behemoth lives in the waters of the remotest oceans. It lures sea dwellers to their deaths with dancing motes of light within its massive, ballooning gullet. Rumors abound that even a sharp pinprick will deflate the sea monster.

entries.name: Gulper Behemoth's Lair
entries: The gulper's lair is filled with brightly-colored and labyrinthine giant corals. Smaller, mutualistic predators swim throughout the lair, keeping it well protected.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The haleshi can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Charming Defense
entries: While the haleshi is wearing no armor and wielding no {@item shield|phb}, its AC includes its Charisma modifier (included in the Armor Class).

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The haleshi's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The haleshi makes two attacks with its stupefying touch.

action.name: Stupefying Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d8 + 3}) psychic damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition incapacitated} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Clamport (3/Day)
entries: The haleshi touches a clam within 5 feet of it, which enlarges and swallows the haleshi and up to three willing Medium or smaller creatures within 15 feet of the haleshi. The clam then teleports to a body of water the haleshi has visited that is large enough to hold the clam's passengers and releases them. After releasing the passengers, the clam returns to normal.

reaction.name: Water Shield {@recharge 5}
entries: The haleshi adds 3 to its AC against one attack that would hit it. To do so, the haleshi must be within 5 feet of a gallon or more of water. Alternatively, if the haleshi would take fire damage from an attack or spell, it can negate that damage if it is within 5 feet of a gallon or more of water.
A tall, gangly humanoid creature with pale-green skin and the head of a mackerel strides out of the water. It wears a loose-fitting tunic and carries a clamshell in its long, spindly hands.

entries.name: Diplomatic Fey
entries: Haleshi are fey that act as intermediaries between fey who live on the land and those who live in oceans and rivers, settling disputes that arise between the two groups. Haleshi are impartial in their rulings and prefer to make decisions based on evidence rather than rumor and speculation. The job of an haleshi is a difficult one due to the chaotic and unpredictable nature of many fey, but they usually receive the backing of the fey lords, particularly the {@creature River King|ToB} ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}), whose court they frequent, and the {@creature Bear King|ToB} ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}), who admires their stoic adherence to duty in the face of adversity.

entries.name: Clam Riders
entries: Haleshi have a mystical connection with ordinary clams and similar mollusks and are able to use mollusks to magically transport themselves from one body of water to another.

entries.name: Food-Lovers
entries: While haleshi have little to do with humanoids in their role as fey diplomats and judges, they have a predilection for human and elven cuisine, particularly desserts such as apple pies and strawberry tartlets. Some fey try to bribe haleshi with human or elven sweets, only to find that the fey are all but incorruptible.

walk.condition: (0 ft., fly 40 ft. in head form)

trait.name: Detachable Head
entries: As a bonus action, the hantu penanggal detaches its head. The head trails entrails like flexible tentacles. While detached, the head and body act independently from each other on the same initiative, and each has hp equal to half its hp before detaching its head. Its statistics remain the same in both forms, except the body loses its {@sense truesight} and gains {@sense blindsight} out to a range of 60 feet.

The head and body can use the whole form's innate spellcasting trait, expending daily uses as normal. The two forms can rejoin into the fiend's whole form as a bonus action if they are within 5 feet of each other. If the head is destroyed while it is detached, the body also perishes. If the body is destroyed while the head is detached, the head has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until it acquires a new body.

A creature within 30 feet of the penanggal and that can see the detachment must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The hantu penanggal's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: When detached, the hantu penanggal's head makes one bite attack and one entrails attack, and its body makes two claw attacks. In its whole form, it can make three rapier attacks.

action.name: Rapier (Whole Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Claw (Body Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Bite (Head Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage, and the target's hp maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken, and the penanggal regains hp equal to that amount. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hp maximum to 0. A humanoid slain in this way becomes the new body for the penanggal, if it is detached and its body died. Otherwise, the humanoid rises 24 hours later as a new hantu penanggal.

action.name: Entrails (Head Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the penanggal can't use its entrails on another target.
The head of a beautiful woman flies through the air, trailing tentacle-like entrails while her headless body follows, bearing demonic claws.

entries.name: Cursed Nature
entries: Hantu penanggal arise when creatures pledged to fiendish powers break their agreements. They are cursed, becoming fiends hungering for the flesh and blood of the innocent.

entries.name: Mistaken for Undead
entries: Hantu penanggal are often mistaken for undead and don't correct this error, finding delight in taking advantage of adventurers ill-prepared for an encounter with a fiend.

monster.name: Harbinger of Wrath

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with adamantine weapons

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Adamantine Weapons
entries: The harbinger's weapon attacks are adamantine and magical.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The harbinger is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the harbinger fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The harbinger has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The harbinger of wrath makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +15} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}36 ({@damage 6d8 + 9}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}) if it is a Large or smaller creature and the harbinger doesn't have two other creatures {@condition grappled}.

action.name: Impale
entries: The harbinger makes one slam attack against a creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, the target is impaled on the harbinger's spikes. While impaled, the creature is {@condition restrained} and takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) piercing damage at the start of each of the harbinger's turns. A creature, including the impaled target, can take its action to free the impaled target by succeeding on a {@dc 20} Strength check. A freed creature falls {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the harbinger. If the harbinger dies, a creature is no longer {@condition restrained} and can escape from the harbinger's spikes by using 10 feet of movement.

action.name: Drain Life {@recharge 5}
entries: The harbinger drains the life force of one creature impaled on its spikes. The target must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw or take 55 ({@damage 10d10}) necrotic damage. If a creature dies from this attack, its soul is absorbed into the harbinger and can be restored to life only by means of a {@spell wish} spell. The harbinger then regains hp equal to the necrotic damage dealt.

action.name: Spike Volley {@recharge 5}
entries: The harbinger launches a volley of adamantine spikes. Each creature within 60 feet of the harbinger must make a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw, taking 42 ({@damage 12d6}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
Twisting adamantine spikes topped with an array of demonic and bestial skulls form the vaguely humanoid creature. It makes a loud screeching sound as it crushes everything in its path.

entries.name: Engines of Decimation
entries: The harbinger of wrath is a construct of immense size and destructive potential. Just seeing a harbinger causes most creatures to flee in terror, and few are willing or able to face one in battle. Creatures allied with a harbinger must also fear its terrible wrath, as it is not against skewering its allies on its many spikes to rejuvenate itself in the heat of battle.

entries.name: Forged by Demons
entries: The first harbingers were created in vast demonic forges by a powerful demon prince to use against his enemies. Since then, the construction process has passed to other demon princes and evil gods that delight in devastation and mayhem.

entries.name: Construct Nature
entries: A harbinger doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The harefolk has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Ready for Trouble
entries: The harefolk can't be surprised, and it has advantage on initiative rolls if it isn't {@condition incapacitated} or {@condition unconscious}.

trait.name: Shapechanger Sensitivity
entries: The harefolk has advantage on Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) and Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks to determine if a creature is a shapechanger. It automatically succeeds when the shapechanger is a {@creature werewolf}. In addition, the harefolk has advantage on its first attack roll each turn against a creature with the Shapechanger trait or Change Shape action, regardless of whether the harefolk was previously aware of the shapechanger's nature.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The harefolk has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Snow Walker
entries: The harefolk can move across icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +4} bis zum Treffer, Reichweite 5 ft., ein Ziel. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) Stich-Schaden.

action.name: Sling
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +4} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

What appears to be an arctic hare given humanoid form is clad in leather armor and stands with its shortsword at the ready. Its bright eyes take everything in, while its nose quivers in search of predators.

entries.name: Werewolf Foes
entries: Harefolk have a long-standing hatred for {@creature werewolf|mm|werewolves}, owing to their near extinction at the lycanthropes' jaws. All present-day harefolk know the story of Mathilda Lopear who, along with an adventuring band of humans (often downplayed or removed from stories about Mathilda), fought and killed a werewolf tribe and saved the lives of the last remaining harefolk clans. Because of this ancient enmity toward werewolves, harefolk are wary of other lycanthropes and shapechangers, even primarily good-aligned creatures such as {@creature werebear|mm|werebears}.

entries.name: Rabbit Tenders
entries: Harefolk keep {@creature hare|idrotf|arctic hares} and other rabbits capable of surviving in arctic climes as pets. They believe the presence of rabbits brings good luck to a clan. Nomadic clans of harefolk ensure their pets can forage grasses as they travel, while more domestic clans grow gardens of hardy vegetables to feed the rabbits. Since harefolk are omnivorous, supplementing their diet of grubs and other insects with vegetation they find or grow, their dietary needs keep them from competing with their pets for resources. Though they are capable of eating flesh from other creatures, their bond with rabbits keeps many harefolk from hunting game animals, including non-rabbits. Adventuring harefolk often bring along a rabbit as a companion animal or familiar.

entries.name: Pranksters
entries: Harefolk enjoy pulling harmless tricks on each other, and stories of memorable pranks are passed down through generations. When dealing with their enemies, harefolk pranks turn injurious if not lethal. One of their favorite tricks is to seed areas beneath the snow with {@item hunting trap|phb|snares} and {@trap bear trap|xge|bear traps}. As they lead pursuers through these areas, they bound safely over the snow while the creatures pursuing them sink below the surface and set off the traps.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (3/Day)
headerEntries: The egret harpy can innately cast {@spell suggestion}, requiring no material components. Its innate spellcasting ability is {@footnote Charisma|Spell save {@dc 12}.}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The egret harpy makes two attacks: one with its spear and one with its talons.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage, or 7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Wing Buffet {@recharge 5}
entries: The egret harpy beats its wings rapidly. Each Medium or smaller creature within 5 feet of the harpy must make a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) bludgeoning damage and is knocked {@condition prone}. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Guiding Song
entries: The egret harpy sings a magical melody. Each humanoid and giant of the harpy's choice within 300 feet of the harpy has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks to navigate marshes, and difficult terrain composed of mud, standing water, or other features of a marsh doesn't cost it extra movement. The harpy must take a bonus action on its subsequent turns to continue singing. It can stop singing at any time. The song ends if the harpy is {@condition incapacitated}.

The harpy can use an action to end the song and cast {@spell mass suggestion}. Each creature that can hear the harpy's song must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or be affected by the spell for 8 hours. If the harpy chooses to end the song this way, it can't use Guiding Song again until it finishes a long rest.
This winged female has a short torso and long, gangly legs. Her wingspan is wider than her body is tall. Despite her awkward appearance, she moves with incredible grace.

entries.name: Protectors of the Marsh
entries: Egret harpies look after marshland flora and fauna, often allying themselves with druids and rangers who occupy the same area.

entries.name: Uncommonly Hospitable
entries: While most harpies have a reputation for sadism and bloodlust, egret harpies are considerably more welcoming. They possess the same alluring song all harpies have, but they can modulate the song to allow their captivated targets safe passage toward them. They often use their songs to prevent intruders from harming their home marshes. They can end their song in a mighty crescendo, imposing their will on those charmed by the song. The harpies typically coerce intruders to repair damages wreaked upon the marsh or to merely leave and never return. If a harpy suspects the intruders are unrepentant, she stops playing nice and allows her victims to fall prey to the marsh's hazards.

entries.name: Powerful Yet Graceful
entries: The wings that hold the egret harpy's larger frame aloft also serve as weapons. A powerful buffet from the harpy's wing can knock down weaker foes. The harpy's gawky build belies a fluidity to her movements, allowing her to balance on one leg even while engaged in battle.

trait.name: Cat Sneak
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the heggarna has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide. It can use this trait only while it is disguised as a cat.

trait.name: Dream Eating
entries: As a bonus action, the heggarna can attach its lamprey-like maw to a sleeping creature. The target's Charisma score is reduced by {@dice 1d4} when the heggarna first attaches to it. The target's Charisma score is then reduced by 1 for each hour the heggarna stays attached. The target dies if this reduces its Charisma to 0. Otherwise, the reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest at least 24 hours after the heggarna reduced its Charisma.

While attached, the heggarna fills the target's dreams with nightmares. The target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or it doesn't gain any benefit from its current rest. If the target succeeds on the saving throw by 5 or more, it immediately awakens.
The heggarna can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement. It does so after it reduces the target's Charisma by 8 or if the target dies.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) psychic damage.

action.name: Dream Rift {@recharge 5}
entries: The heggarna unleashes a barrage of psychic energy in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage and is {@condition incapacitated} until the end of its next turn as it is bombarded with nightmarish images. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Illusory Apperance
entries: The heggarna covers itself with a magical illusion that makes it look like a Tiny {@creature cat}. The illusion ends if the heggarna takes a bonus action to end it or if the heggarna dies. The illusion ends immediately if the heggarna attacks or takes damage, but it doesn't end when the heggarna uses Dream Eating.

The changes wrought by this effect fail to hold up to physical inspection. For example, the heggarna could appear to have fur, but someone touching it would feel its slippery flesh. Otherwise, a creature must take an action to visually inspect the illusion and succeed on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to discern the heggarna is disguised.
The foul abomination wriggles about on multiple caterpillar-like claspers. It has the jagged, circular maw and slippery body of an oversized leech and the head and coloration of a fierce tiger.

entries.name: Night Terrors
entries: Many sleepers have experienced nightmares in which a shadowy creature was sitting on them, draining them of their vital essence. While most of these experiences are because of some underlying psychological trauma, some are the result of visitations by terrifying creatures of the night. One such creature is the heggarna, a vile aberration that feeds on a creature's mental energy as it sleeps and infuses the victim's subconscious with terrible nightmares for its own vile amusement.

entries.name: Hidden Fear
entries: During the day, the heggarna disguises itself as a stray cat, lurking near the homes of potential prey and fleeing with feline-like caution when anyone comes near. Most humanoids overlook simple animals like cats when dealing with a heggarna infestation, but magic can detect the creature's true appearance. Normal animals react to the heggarna with a strange ferocity, which experienced hunters recognize as a sign of a heggarna.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (1/Day)
headerEntries: The helashruu can innately cast {@spell gate}, requiring no material components. Its innate spellcasting ability is Charisma.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The helashruu uses Trap Life if it can. It then makes four shard whip attacks.

action.name: Shard Whip
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Reflect Energy {@recharge 5}
entries: The helashruu releases stored energy in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 35 ({@damage 10d6}) damage of the most recent type dealt to the helashruu on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the helashruu hasn't taken damage within the past 1 minute, the damage type is force.

action.name: Trap Life {@recharge 6}
entries: One creature of the helashruu's choice that is within 30 feet of the helashruu and that can see it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or be trapped inside the helashruu's mirror. While trapped, the target is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the helashruu, and it takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) force damage at the start of each of the helashruu's turns. The helashruu can have only one creature trapped at a time. A fragmented caricature of the trapped creature appears on the helashruu's surface while a creature is trapped inside it.

If the helashruu takes 30 or more bludgeoning or thunder damage on a single turn, the helashruu must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or release the creature, which falls {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the helashruu. If the helashruu dies, a trapped creature is immediately released into a space within 10 feet of the helashruu.

action.name: Teleport
entries: The helashruu magically teleports, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space it can see.

action.name: Dimensional Hop (3/Day)
entries: The helashruu can transport itself to a different plane of existence. This works like the {@spell plane shift} spell, except the helashruu can affect only itself and can't use this action to banish an unwilling creature to another plane.

An enormous looking glass floats forward, its enormous, warped frame composed of writhing purple tendrils, and its surface covered in dozens of hideous, swirling eyes. Several razor-sharp whips whirl through the air around it.

entries.name: Mirrors from Beyond
entries: The helashruu are bizarre and terrifying aberrations that travel the planes, spreading chaos and destruction. Resembling towering mirrors covered in tentacles and eyes, helashruu defy rational explanation. When they deem it necessary to communicate with other creatures, it is usually through a jumbled mishmash of thoughts with their telepathy, though making sense of what they say is often next to impossible.

entries.name: Trapping Gone Astray
entries: Sages versed in planar lore believe the helashruu were created when a {@item mirror of life trapping} swallowed a powerful, deity of chaos and shattered under the strain of the energies it tried to contain. The pieces then scattered across the planes before forming into the first helashruu. The helashruu sometimes trap creatures within themselves, giving credence to this belief. Some sages hypothesize that if all the helashruu were to gather together in one place, they would reform the original mirror, and the evil entity would be released from its confinement. Thankfully, these creatures are extremely rare and hold nothing but contempt for others of their own kind.

trait.name: Corrupting Aura
entries: The {@spell calm emotions} spell instantly fails when cast within 60 feet of the herald. In addition, any creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the herald must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or grow hostile. On its turn, a hostile creature must move to and make one attack against the nearest creature other than the herald. If no other creature is near enough to move to and attack, the hostile creature stalks off in a random direction, seeking a target for its hostility.  At the start of each of the herald's turn, it chooses whether this aura is active.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The herald's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Shapechanger
